key_points: Australia has stopped evacuation flights from Afghanistan following Islamic State suicide bombings.
The attacks killed scores of civilians and at least 13 U.S. military personnel.
Australia's military personnel were evacuated from Kabul hours before the attacks.
Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated evacuations are no longer safe, shifting to a post-evacuation phase focusing on a humanitarian program.
Despite Australia's halt, some Western countries have accelerated evacuations, with flights still departing.
Some Australian visa holders remain in Afghanistan, with unknown exact numbers.
Morrison warns Australians and visa holders unlikely to get seats on remaining flights.
Australia has evacuated 4,100 citizens and Afghans with visas in the last nine days.
Foreign Minister Marise Payne advises Australians and visa holders to avoid the airport due to risk of further attacks.
Australia seeks to determine if any citizens or residents were among the casualties of the Kabul attacks.
